meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: really important um aspect of this because I think right now like we're focusing on like these spatial um networks which uh to me does sound like a little loosely defined like the example I've been using um is you know the the classical connectomics example um but then there the dynamic um the dynamic networks and to me like it it I am more interested in those um I'll just say.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: It it may also be particularly important to if you're linking across these scales to use the same individuals that you're you're using, you know, it might be challenging to take the molecular, you know, uh say like spatial transcriptomics data from one individual and then link it to the neural activity of another or to the connectivity of another. I think there's enough individual to individual variability where some of the explanation that can bridge those different levels uh would be best served if it can be across the same individual.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: That goes against what you're just saying about registering things into a common space, right? So

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, you can register the same individual across multiple levels, right? You can look at the same, you know, thousand neurons for their activity and then try and figure out what genes they're expressing and then figure out how they're connected to one another. But I think it, you know, and then look for principles, have a number of individuals to compare, but I think there can be a challenge of trying to take uh just the spatial uh transcriptomics data from a group of animals and then uh neural activity from a separate group and then trying to link those together.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, we we so we have a temporal issue with our work because we're doing mass spectrometry imaging, which again involves slicing and freezing tissue, right? Um and then mapping the chemistry across it. Um but you can to a certain extent, it depends on the time, but if you have enough samples, if you have enough replicates, you can look at time and how that changes. So for example, we're looking at root regeneration, you cut off the tip of the root, you can measure um regeneration occurs over a couple days. So, you know, you take as many samples as you can, you cut them up and and you can image them. And if you could do something like that with the brain, with the with the transcriptomics, with the electron microscopy, I mean that would be a really powerful way um in the same section to get a lot of information potentially over time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: I like this idea of of just needing uh of replicates, right? So I've started taking all of my data and so I collect whole brain data and now I register all of that into the Allen Brain common coordinate framework, whether I need to or not. And it's changed the way that I look at my data instead of seeing how individuals change and then trying to do statistics and put them together, I start thinking about, well, how do I build models out of the data as it is. And if it doesn't, if it doesn't work, then I need to collect the data in a different way to get it to fit into a larger model of some biological process. And it's this mixture of registering of registering data sets versus trying to use that registered data to build a model that can be applied to a stereotypical version of the thing. So that's something I've been struggling with, when do you register and when is it just data you collect to get replicates.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Molly Bright
meeting_annotations.transcript: Something that um has been kind of putting a few things together has me wondering if other people run into the same issue I have with people, which is the same network will behave incredibly differently every time you look at it. And so we have this this it seems like a conflict of saying, do we want a huge amount of subjects or do we want a really deep dive into one subject or five subjects and to understand that variability and what it means. And and I think, you know, very different labs go in very different directions and then we end up viewing things with a very different lens that can eventually be hard to reconcile. Um but I I think there must be a way that we're we're trying to get at the same things, but we're just going about it really focusing on that that subtle constant variation of what happens within a network you identify and what happens in that network you identify when you look at it once in a many different subjects. Um and it's something I yeah, I'm still wrapping my head around. I know which side I do, but I don't know how you sort of engage with the other lens.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Boziyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: So that's something that I think can be addressed um with simpler systems like, you know, fish that are see through or C elegans where we know how the cells all connect. I mean,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Boziyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: What are your thoughts Corey actually about that in terms of how how how what we can learn from, you know, being able to do those studies in a lot of a lot of worms in a very controlled way as supposed to a human where now you have to have a lot more sort of variability in terms of the stimuli and other things.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cori Bargmann
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I don't think it's I I I should be listening first of all, but I'll answer this one question and then I'll go back to listening. Um, I think that the, you know, you actually gain different pieces of information from looking at at one event over a long period of time and from looking at multiple event snapshots of multiple events. And they each provide value and so it's not an either or situation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cori Bargmann
meeting_annotations.transcript: Jeff Lichtman's neural development example was always like, you know, it's he was always very contemptuous of not doing a time series. He said you couldn't understand a football game if you just looked at snapshots of many football games. But in fact, biology is not a football game and there's certain things that do happen and well defined patterns.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cori Bargmann
meeting_annotations.transcript: But

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: Scott

meeting_annotations.speaker: Doug Shepherd
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I mean this information idea, I think, you know, from us, which again is more of like a cell and like I mean one thing we've been really pushing everyone to think about is if you do have a model or you do have something you think is true, you know, can you do a bit more like truly quantitative experimental design for which is like what axes do you need to expand the information that you're collecting more statistics along to test something, right? And actually this has turned out to meet a lot of headlong resistance across different groups of, oh, well, we just need all of it. But this is not a tenable thing and quite often people don't use the data. So from our sense, we're really trying to understand like if you really want to answer, I don't know, how network A functions and you have some idea of how it's connected, can you come up with some sort of sort of framework which tells you something, right? And you can pick different metrics like fish information or something to then ask like, you know, along what ways am I most variable that I should fill this out to reduce the uncertainty in how it's acting. And I think there's a big lack of that in designing big imaging experiments at the moment where it's just let's just take a lot of data. Uh and again, this is from the molecular and kind of cellular point of view. I don't deal with people. So I'm sure there's different things in designing experiments with people, but this is my point of view.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, and when you have you get a you're looking at a large data set and you have a question, a biological hypothesis or a question from that data set. If you don't have access to collecting that data yourself, I mean, how can you test out your hypothesis? You have to have the tools to ex to to conduct your own perturbations of the the biological system that that is in these data sets and I think that's a major challenge for researchers.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: Do you think the data, do you think that these sorts of projects could be collected in a more interactive way where all participants kind of lay out what directions they would want to go in and then compromises are made sort of in the initial the initial setup to allow for it to be more accessible to small scale, smaller scale hypothesis testing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: That would be really cool.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, you know, going into the project with a range of scientists with, you know, you know, some of who are very specific hypothesis driven would be valuable in in addition to the kind of more technologically driven people, maybe.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Boziyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: Are there platforms for this sort of stuff? meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, that's certainly possible, but someone has to like devote like the time um and energy and the resources to build to build something like that. And just generally speaking, it's a non-trivial effort to put image collection um resources together.
